thread.title: Malakai Fekitoa confirms interest from overseas clubs ahead of contract year
thread.title_full: Malakai Fekitoa confirms interest from overseas clubs ahead of contract year

author: Robert van Royen
title: Malakai Fekitoa confirms interest from overseas clubs ahead of contract year
text:
Malakai Fekitoa confirms interest from overseas clubs ahead of contract year ROBERT VAN ROYEN Last updated 17:19, February 23 2017 ROB JEFFERIES/GETTY IMAGES 
Malakai Fekitoa will play his 50th game for the Highlanders against the Chiefs on Friday night. 
If it was up to Highlanders co-captain Ben Smith, teammate Malakai Fekitoa will follow his lead by signing on the dotted line and stay put. 
The 24-year-old midfielder is off contract with the Highlanders and New Zealand Rugby (NZR) at the end of the year and admitted he was open to looking elsewhere, including overseas. 
Fekitoa and teammate Waisake Naholo, who is also off contract this year, are both players the Highlanders and NZR would dearly like to hold on to, but the reality is they can't stop everyone from turning down lucrative overseas deals. CLAY CROSS/PHOTOSPORT 
Malakai Fekitoa in action during last week's pre-season game against the Waratahs in Sydney. 
"Obviously this is my last season [contracted] here and also with NZ Rugby, but I don't know what's going to pop up after this," Fekitoa said. 
READ MORE 
"I would love to stay or maybe look elsewhere. I don't know, I'll just have to see what's best for me and my career and also for my family. ROB JEFFERIES/GETTY IMAGES 
Malakai Fekitoa on the charge against the Hurricanes during last year's Super Rugby campaign. 
"But I love it down here, it's been fun." 
Fekitoa, who will play his 50th game for the Highlanders against the Chiefs in Dunedin on Friday night, said "a few" overseas clubs had been in touch with him and his management regarding a change next year. 
"I can't say much about it, but the door has been knocking, yeah." 
Smith, who recently rebuffed a huge offer from French side Pau to stay in New Zealand through to 2020, said Fekitoa represented what the Highlanders are about. Ad Feedback 
"I'd love to see Malakai sign for another 20 years," he said. "He's awesome and he's great for the Highlanders." 
However, as good as he was his first two years with the team after moving south from the Blues, Fekitoa hit a speed bump last year. 
Unforced errors crept into his game and his ability to break teams open with his raw power mostly escaped him. 
It resulted in him battling for game time in the black jersey during last year's end-of-year-tour, with Chiefs midfielder Anton Lienert-Brown unseating him in the pecking order. 
"Obviously it didn't go well last year towards the end," Fekitoa said. "The [British and Irish] Lions are coming up, now I have an opportunity to start again tomorrow against the Chiefs. 
"Hopefully I can do my job and get my confidence back and enjoy my footy." 
Fekitoa will be matched up with Lienert-Brown under the roof in the season opener, and is relishing the opportunity to test himself against a player he said has got certain skills other midfielders in the country don't have. 
But Tongan-born Fekitoa, who has played 23 tests for the All Blacks, has been busy during the off-season working on the new and improved version of himself. 
He said increasing his speed was a "massive work-on" during the break, while he had also been focussing on improving his footwork. 
ï»¿ "I've always wanted to be the best in the world at what I do as a midfielder, as a centre," Fekitoa said. 
Fekitoa said reaching the 50-match milestone was something he was proud of, and he would celebrate with friends and family post match.
